Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Ayres Freitas and Adam Leibovich at the University of Pittsburgh.

This purpose of this project is to develop improved theoretical tools and calculational methods for the robust, model-independent interpretation of results from current and future particle-physics experiments, both at the highest-energy colliders, such as the Large Hadron Collider, and for lower-energy precision measurements. The identification of a potentially small signal of new physics requires an excellent understanding of known particles and interactions. Furthermore, we will investigate techniques for model-independent descriptions of the effects of new physics, using a framework called "effective field theories". As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. In conjunction with this effort, the PI's will also teach a special-topics course on effective field theories and precision physics. Both are topics that are often neglected in typical particle-physics textbooks.

More technically, the research program can be divided into three main parts: (1) The development of calculational techniques for three-loop corrections to electroweak precision observables, and the integration of existing and new theoretical results for these observables into a flexible, object-oriented computer program; (2) The application of effective field theories, in particular Soft-Collinear Effective Theory, to unresolved questions at hadron colliders, such as processes involving jets, quarkonium production, and low-x physics; and (3) A comprehensive study of the use of effective field theories for new physics in Higgs, electroweak and flavor physics, with a focus on investigating correlations between operators, the role of different mass scales in the new-physics sector, and complications that arise in models of dark matter. This research plan is guided by ongoing and planned experimental high-energy physics efforts, and results will be made available to the experimental community in a suitable form.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Current and future particle physics experiments provide us with data of unprecendented amount and quality that can be used to scrutinize the fundamental interactions of elementary particles to very high precision. Signs of new physics may first be seen as relatively small deviations from the expectation in some measurements. To make this possible, high-accuracy theory calculations are needed. The majority of the work done for this grant was devoted to carrying out these calculations with innovative and improved techniques. There are a number of different areas that were targeted for this: precise calculations of the strong interactions, with is relevant for physics at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC); precise calculations of the weak interactions, in particular for planned future electron-positron facilities; precise calculations of jets of particles produced in particle collisions; new calculations of the production of quarkonium within these jets of particles; and precise calculations of gravitaional wave emission from black-hole binaries. The last item is currently of high interest owing to the recent first direct observations of gravitational waves by the LIGO collaboration and several new gravitational wave detectors currently under development.

Another aspect of the work done for this grant was working on new, unkonwn physics beyond the standard model. This more speculative work could help our understanding of the ultimate more complete theory of nature. The work performed under this grant included studies of dark matter possibilities, potential new heavy particles, and hypothetical new dimensions beyond the three spatial dimensions. In recent years, it has been realized that the range of suitable new physics models is much broader than previously thought, so that more model-independent theory approaches are called for. This was achieved through the use of effective field theories and simplified model descriptions, as well as identifying and understanding conceptial features. The work on jets may also be useful in this context, because jet production rates are very large in the Standard Model, so that new physics contributions are difficult to dig out from this background.

All of this work pushes our knowledge of fundamental physics beyond what was previously known. The work will allow us to obtain useful information out of the current and future particle physics (and gravitational wave physics) experiments and will help in searching for the new physics that we know must exist.

The broader impacts of the work include training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, all of whom moved on to successful next career steps after their time in Pittsburgh. We have published our results for the rest of the community and have released public computer codes that allow others access to the tools developed. We have also been working with experimentalists to design new or improved analysis techniques, as well as to develop the physics case of future experiments.
